markdownRemark.html:
⚠️ I assume you have basic knowledge about git, and that you are familiar with its index, working tree as well as commands like reset and cherry-pick

There are lots of commands in git and you can often achieve your goal in several different ways. I usually manage to get my stuff done with just few cmds like rebase, reset, cherry-pick. But sometimes I felt I was doing it in an ineffective way though. Like for example squashing all commits into a single one so that it is easier to rebase afterward 🙈 Even though I knew that rebasing with the --onto option would be useful, I never took the time to man it… until recently.

I guess now is a good time to write something about it (Actually I just want to inaugurate my blog… any reason is a good reason 😝)

When could --onto option be useful?

Here are some use-cases:

  • you want to cherry-pick multiples commits
  • you have created a branch from the ‘wrong’ one and you want to start over from the ‘right’ one
  • you want to delete a range of commits

Basically it all comes down to this: apply a range of commits somewhere else

Rebase in its simplest form

Lets begin with a little reminder about how rebase works in its simplest form. From the man (unix) we get:

git rebase upstream [branch]

I am gonna give some examples and intentionally avoid any short-hand way at first.

When you run the command git rebase master topic then:

  1. Git will position HEAD → topic
  2. The index and working tree are reset to master. This is exactly like running git reset --hard master except that changes to tracked files in the working tree are saved somewhere for later use
  3. those commits are applied one by one. This is like “cherry-picking” them

Note if you already are on the topic branch (HEAD → topic) then you can omit the [branch] arg and just type git rebase master. This is a common short hand.

To summarize all of the following scenarios are equivalents:

git rebase master topic

Which is basically:

git checkout topic
git rebase master

Or if HEAD →→→ topic the short-hand 

git rebase master

Which is basically the same as

git reset --hard master
git cherry-pick E
git cherry-pick F
git cherry-pick G

How about the --onto option?

git rebase --onto newbase upstream [branch]

The only difference is in step 1. Git will hard reset to newbase instead of upstream. Step 2 remains the same, commits upstream + 1 .. branch are applied. Commits between upstream (excluded) and branch (included) are applied

%% ouverture

Feel the power of -i option

The -i option is one of my favorite one because it lets you squash, delete, rename, edit… basically playing with the past !! ❤️ but this is another story
